required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Chewing Duration on Blood Glucose Levels
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Chewing Duration on Blood Glucose Levels

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to assess the impact of speed of consumption of two starch-based foods varying in fibre content on blood glucose levels in normal healthy subjects. Furthermore, the mediating roles of salivary amylase and particle size on blood glucose levels will be studied. The study has a randomized cross-over design. Subjects consume two test-lunches (chick peas and brown rice) in duplicate on 8 different test days, at either long or short chewing duration. Glucose responses will be monitored via a continuous glucose monitoring device and expectorated boluses will be collected during each test day for assessments of amylase activity and food particle size.

detailed_description.textblock:
Research suggests that high glucose level variability and large dips in glucose levels may have a negative impact on cognitive function and self-reported wellbeing. The way food is consumed (e.g. chewing duration) may regulate blood glucose levels. The underlying mechanism that links consumption speed to metabolic responses, satiation and health is largely unknown.
This study aims to assess the impact of speed of consumption of two starch-based foods varying in fibre content, on blood glucose levels in normal healthy subjects. Furthermore, the mediating roles of salivary amylase and particle size on blood glucose levels are studied.
The study has a randomized cross-over design. Each subject consumes two different test-lunches (chick peas and brown rice) in duplicate at either long or short duration. Their breakfast will be standardized during these 8 test days. For a duration of 12 days, blood glucose levels will be monitored via a continuous glucose device. Furthermore expectorated boluses will be collected for assessment of amylase activity and food particle size.

primary_outcome.measure: Blood glucose responses in the 3 hrs following lunch
primary_outcome.time_frame: 12 days in total to cover all test days
primary_outcome.description: measured by a continuous glucose monitoring device

secondary_outcome.time_frame: on 4 of the 8 test days, at day 1, day 2, day 3 and day 4 or day 5, day 6, day 7 and day 8 depending on group
secondary_outcome.description: measured in food boli of the test-lunches by image analysis

secondary_outcome.measure: In vitro starch digestion rates in food bolus
secondary_outcome.time_frame: on 4 of the 8 test days, at day 1, day 2, day 3 and day 4 or day 5, day 6, day 7 and day 8 depending on group
secondary_outcome.description: assessed in food boli of the test-lunches by making use of INFOGEST 2.0 protocol

arm_group.description: Subjects consume two starch-based foods varying in fibre content e.g. brown rice and chick-peas in duplicate following a short chewing protocol.
Subjects will consume two starch-based foods varying in fibre content e.g. brown rice and chick-peas in duplicate following a long chewing protocol.

intervention.intervention_name: Low glycaemic load, high fibrous product
intervention.description: Test-lunch of 370 grams of chickpeas, seasoned with a herb- and spice mix to increase palatability. Glycaemic load 18.5. Consumed in duplicate.

intervention.intervention_name: High glycaemic load, low fibrous product
intervention.description: Test-lunch of 257 grams of brown rice, seasoned with rice-oil and a herb- and spice mix to increase palatability. Glycaemic load 44.9. Consumed in duplicate.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Apparently healthy men and women (based on questionnaire, self-reported)
- Aged between 18 - 55 yrs
- BMI between 18.5 - 30 kg/m2
- In possession of a Smartphone running on iOS or Android
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosed with Diabetes mellitus type 1 or 2
- Under treatment for neurological or psychiatric complaints, including eating disorders
- History of gastro-intestinal surgery or having (serious) gastro-intestinal complaints
- Use of medication/supplements that may influence the study results, such as medicines known to interfere with glucose homeostasis. This will be judged by our medical doctor
- Following a diet or gained/lost >=5kg weight in the previous month.
- Coeliac disease or gluten intolerance
- Skin allergy, eczema or known sensitivity for plasters
- use of drugs
- Current smokers
- Using > 14 glasses of alcohol per week
- Having a food allergy for the test foods
- Participation in another clinical trial at the same time
- Suffering from a stomach emptying disorder
- Employed by or an intern at the FHCR group of Wageningen Food & Biobased Research.
